Abstract ١ During the last few decades, several studies have suggested that carbon-based ٢ nanomaterials, owing to their unique properties, could act as promising candidates in biomedical ٣ engineering application. Wide-ranging research efforts have investigated the cellular and ٤ molecular responses to carbon-based nanomaterials at the nano-bio interfaces. In addition, a ٥ number of surface functionalization strategies have been introduced to improve their safety ٦ profile in the biological environment. The present review discusses the general principles of ٧ immunological responses to nanomaterials. Then, it explains essential physico-chemical ٨ properties of carbon-family nanomaterials, including carbon nanotubes (CNTs), graphene, ٩ fullerene, carbon quantum dots (CDs), diamond-like carbon (DLC), and mesoporous carbon ١٠ biomaterials (MCNs), which significantly affect the immunological cellular and molecular ١١ responses at the nano-bio interface. The discussions also briefly highlight the recent studies that ١٢ critically investigated the cellular and molecular responses to various carbon-based nanomaterials. ١٣ It is expected that the most recent perspective strategies for improving the biological responses ١٤ to carbon-based nanomaterials can revolutionize their functions in emerging biological ١٥ applications. ١٦
Keywords: Carbon; Carbon nanotubes (CNTs); Graphene; Fullerene; Carbon quantum dots (CDs); ١٧ Diamond-like carbon (DLC); Biomaterials; Nanomaterials; Nano-Bio Interface; Immunological ١٨ Responses. ١٩

1. Introduction ١ Biomaterials science is a multidisciplinary field of study which aims to introduce biological ٢ alternatives for biomedical purposes, such as improving tissue and/or organ regeneration [1, 2]. ٣ In today’s medicine world, there is an ever-increasing demand for providing promising ٤ biomaterials, which could lead to more accurate disease diagnosis and treatment [3, 4]. In other ٥ hand, nanomedicine is a promising field of study, parallel with other strategies, aims to ٦ revolutionize the treatment pathways [5, 6]. Based on the definition established by National ٧ Nanotechnology Initiative (NNI), the field of nanomaterials describes using materials which have ٨ at least one length scale ranged between single atomic and one hundred nanometers for ٩ fabricating novel systems [7-9]. Owing to the well-acknowledged fact that most of the biological ١٠ components involve some sort of nano-dimensionality, nanomaterials have currently gained an ١١ increasing attention among biomedical scientists [7, 10]. Carbon-based nanomaterials, such as ١٢ fullerenes, carbon nanotubes (CNTs), and graphene sheets have received considerable attentions ١٣ among biomedical scientists for multiple emerging applications [11-13]. Carbon-based ١٤ nanomaterials owing to their excellent mechanical, electrical and physical properties, suggest ١٥ novel promising cues in various fields of biomedicine, such as tissue engineering, delivery systems, ١٦ and even cancer therapy [14, 15]. As an example, some recent studies have shown that these ١٧ materials can be potentially employed to fabricate electrically conductive scaffolds with the ability ١٨ to provide controlled electrical stimulation [16, 17]. These nanomaterials are promising candidates ١٩ for developing synthetic bio-scaffolds as suitable platforms in the field of tissue regeneration, as ٢٠ the scaffolds in this area need to precisely mimic the physicochemical and mechanical properties ٢١ of native extracellular matrix (ECM). It has been commonly acknowledged that carbon-based ٢٢ Provi sio l
5
nanomaterials due to their similar dimensions are physically similar to ECM constituents [12]. In ١ addition, owing to their excellent mechanical behaviors, these nanomaterials play key roles in ٢ manipulating biological behaviors. Additionally, the great conductivity of carbon-based ٣ nanomaterials could be applied to create or increase the electrical stimulation at the nano-bio ٤ interface [17]. ٥ However, before applying these nanomaterials in the body, their toxicity needs to be ٦ meticulously examined. It is known that all the implanted biomaterials could potentially stimulate ٧ the immunological responses of body, known as foreign body responses (FBRs), which lead to ٨ imperfect functionality in the body [18, 19]. However, FBRs, in other hand, are crucial responses ٩ for destroying cellular debris and subsequently inhibiting the infection progression [20]. ١٠ Therefore, in designing carbon-based nanomaterials carefully considering the details of immune ١١ system responses to the implanted material is essential. During implanting carbon-based ١٢ nanomaterials in the body, the adsorbed proteins, besides macrophages and dendritic cells (DCs) ١٣ are the key players in starting cellular and molecular communications [21]. This review emphasis ١٤ on research concerning carbon-family nanomaterials in biological applications. Here, the general ١٥ principles of immunological responses to the nanomaterials will be discussed. Then, the main body ١٦ of the review goes on the essential physicochemical, and mechanical properties of the key carbon ١٧ nanomaterials including: CNTs, graphene, fullerene, carbon quantum dots (CDs), diamond-like ١٨ carbon (DLC), and mesoporous carbon biomaterials (MCNs), which significantly impact on the ١٩ immunological cells responses. The discussion will then highlight the recent studies that deeply ٢٠ investigate the cellular and molecular responses to various carbon nanomaterial surfaces. Finally, ٢١ Provi siona l
6
the recent strategies which are commonly used for improving the cell responses to carbon-based ١ nanomaterials will be briefly presented. ٢
٣ 2. Principles into immunological responses to nanomaterials ٤ Both innate and adaptive immune systems play crucial roles in responding against any ٥ implanted biomaterial into the body. In fact, FBRs to the implanted biomaterial potentially define ٦ the success or failure of cells-material interactions [19, 22]. It has been demonstrated that the ٧ success of implanted nanomaterials differs reliant on the degree of FBRs and following ٨ homeostatic mechanism which can potentially lead to the cellular and molecular inflammatory ٩ responses. Various humoral and cellular elements are vital to intensify operative immune ١٠ responses. After nanomaterial’s implantation, damaging the blood vessels (as a result of the ١١ surgery) causes interactions between the nanomaterial and blood cells through the proteins’ ١٢ adsorption and also provisional matrix formation on and around the nanomaterial’s surface [23, ١٣ 24]. The provisional matrix is mainly considered as the primary thrombus/blood clot at the ١٤ boundary between tissue and nanomaterial, which provokes structural, biochemical, and cellular ١٥ mechanisms to start regeneration and FBRs processes [25, 26]. In addition, during this stage, ١٦ plasma components such as proteins, lipids, and ions are rapidly adsorbed on the nanomaterial’s ١٧ surface which start triggering and stopping some mechanisms alongside with the formation of ١٨ provisional matrix, which finally consequence in the inflammatory responses [27]. After the ١٩ primary interactions between blood and nanomaterial as well as the development of provisional ٢٠ matrix, acute and chronic inflammation occur in a chronological cascade [28, 29]. Stimulated ٢١ platelets and endothelial cells release chemo-attractants, which consequences in activating ٢٢ Prov siona l
7
neutrophils and acute inflammation phase on the implanted site [30, 31]. Neutrophils through ١ phagocytosis and degranulation mechanisms, challenge to eradicate the nanomaterial. Besides, ٢ complement proteins alongside with some structures including danger-associated molecular ٣ patterns (DAMPs) and pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) start the innate immune ٤ responses. These patterns are accepted by a restricted amount of pattern recognition receptors ٥ (PRRs) which are mainly presented on macrophages and DCs [32]. DCs are antigen-presenting cells ٦ which act as a ‘bridge’ between the innate and adaptive immune system. It has been shown that ٧ binding the patterns to PRRs mainly consequences in activating innate immune system through ٨ releasing pro-inflammatory cytokines, and chemokines that encourage directed chemotaxis of ٩ innate inflammatory cells. It also activates the adaptive immune system through the development ١٠ of DCs that finally causes B and T lymphocytes initiation [33, 34]. The adaptive immune system is ١١ composed of B cells and T cells, which are highly in charge for immunological ‘memory’ [35]. ١٢ During the chronic stage of inflammation, the cytokines source is mainly triggered by T ١٣ lymphocytes, predominantly the T helper (Th) cells which express CD4 and their subsections Th1 ١٤ and Th2. It has been reported that the cytokine production by these cells highly stimulate both ١٥ the pro-inflammatory and anti-inflammatory responses [36]. Additionally, B cells by producing ١٦ antibodies have a key role in immune system responses to nanomaterials. Besides, it should be ١٧ noted that lymphocytes could also adhere to nanomaterials surface through pre-adsorbed ١٨ proteins [37]. In addition to neutrophils, monocytes also reply to the platelet-derived chemo-١٩ attractants placed on the implantation site and make interactions with fibrinogen which finally ٢٠ could cause in their activation [38, 39]. The monocytes link to the temporary provisional matrix on ٢١ the nanomaterial surface through integrins, which play a crucial role in macrophage initiation. ٢٢ P vi sion l
8
These monocytes differentiate into “M1” macrophages at the damage area, which have the talent ١ to release pro-inflammatory cytokines and chemokines [40, 41]. It has been shown that the ٢ macrophages similar to neutrophils challenge to get rid of nanomaterial, prior to experiencing ٣ “frustrated” phagocytosis, eventually causing further pro-inflammatory cytokines activation [41]. ٤ The activated macrophages finally shift to “M2” phenotype which are recognized by decreased ٥ degradative capacity, anti-inflammatory cytokines activation, and starting tissue remodeling ٦ process [42]. Ultimately, in an effort to develop the phagocytic behavior of macrophages, the ٧ formation of foreign body giant cells (FBGCs) on the nanomaterials surface starts, which is mainly ٨ initiated via the stimulation of mast cells, basophils, and Th cells [43-45]. These cells ultimately ٩ release IL-4 and IL-13 which are the key players in creating macrophage fusion [46, 47]. A several ١٠ of studies have shown that macrophages and T lymphocytes stimulated via mature antigen-١١ presenting DCs seem to mainly control the development from chronic inflammation to ١٢ regeneration. In addition, some studies have shown that mast cells also have a great role in ١٣ activating pro- and anti-inflammatory, angiogenic and pro-fibrotic factors [48]. The determined ١٤ action of immune cells consequences in passageways guided at separating the nanomaterial from ١٥ the host tissue by fibrotic encapsulation via pro-fibrogenic factors activation such as platelet-١٦ derived growth factor (PDGF), vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), and transforming growth ١٧ factor beta 1 (TGF-beta 1) [26, 49]. In fact, the stimulated fibroblasts accumulate collagen at the ١٨ implanted site with the aim of repairing the damaged tissue, nevertheless, their unnecessary ١٩ release consequences in fibrosis [39]. If no infection is existent, subsequent to fibrotic ٢٠ encapsulation, the inflammatory reactions eventually will be removed and the implant function ٢١ leads to tissue regeneration. Therefore, in synthesizing nanomaterials for successfully controlling ٢٢ Prov si n l
9
the immune system responses considering the details of immune cells functions, has a great ١ importance that should be taken into account. A brief explanation of FBRs to nanomaterials ٢ surface can be seen in figure 1. Several of parameters such as proteins properties, and ٣ physicochemical properties of nanomaterials surface potentially impact on the types of adsorbed ٤ biomolecules on nanomaterials surface and subsequent responses to it, which regarding carbon-٥ based nanomaterials will be discussed in the next sections. ٦
٧
10
3. The significant role of proteins adsorption on cell-biomaterials interactions ١ The adsorption of proteins potentially regulates a series of principal events at the boundary of ٢ biomaterial-tissue [50, 51]. In fact, the rapid adsorption of proteins on the biomaterial’s surface ٣ starts interpreting the surface characteristics into a biological language [50]. The anchorage and ٤ extracellular directions of cells are extremely dependent on the adsorption of some proteins e.g. ٥ fibronectin (FN), fibrinogen (Fg), vitronectin, complement C3, and albumin (ALB) [50, 52]. Three ٦ key driving forces which play crucial roles in the proteins’ adsorption on the surface of biomaterials ٧ and subsequently cell interactions are including thermodynamically, polarity, and solubility [53]. It ٨ has been reported that thermodynamic, under body environments, could offer a negative free ٩ energy charge for proteins’ adsorption on the surface of biomaterials [54]. Moreover, the proteins’ ١٠ undefined polarity have an influence on their adsorption and prefer a certain level of proteins at ١١ boundaries [55]. Also, there is an opposite connection between protein’s adsorption and its ١٢ solubility [53]. Some studies have proposed that all bindings between proteins and biomaterial’s ١٣ surface are secondary in nature e.g. hydrogen bonding. In addition, the protein’s features that ١٤ principally affect the surface activities of both biomaterials and cells are related to the key ١٥ arrangement of the adsorbed proteins and their amino acids’ sequence [56, 57]. Greater ١٦ molecules because of their larger surface area are more predictable to interact with surfaces [54]. ١٧ In addition, the hydrophilicity of amino acids, could have influences on the protein adsorption [58]. ١٨ Interestingly, the isoelectric point (PI) of proteins could also play a chief role in their adsorption ١٩ [59]. Further, by altering the protein’s conformation, various amino acids could be presented on ٢٠ the protein’s surface, which subsequently change the behavior of adsorbed proteins [60]. The ٢١ possibility of offering more areas for interacting between protein and biomaterials surface, known ٢٢ Pro i si
11
as proteins’ unfolding, is another key factor, which has an oppose association with the proteins’ ١ stability [53]. The accessibility of proteins for making interaction with the biomaterial’s surface ٢ should be also considered [61]. Some studies have reported that the adsorption of proteins on the ٣ surface of biomaterials are principally determined through four key transport mechanisms namely ٤ diffusion, thermal convection, flow, and coupled transport [62]. In other side, cells by their specific ٥ receptors also interact with the adhesive ligands of ECM proteins, which are also adsorbed on the ٦ biomaterial’s surface [53]. The chance of communication between these ligands and cells, is chiefly ٧ dependent on the connections of ECM proteins with the biomaterial’s surface [63]. After ٨ adsorption to the biomaterial’s surface, the ECM proteins, owing to their non-rigid formation, ٩ experience conformational and orientation alterations which consequently have a great effect on ١٠ defining the kinds of available ligands for communications with cell surface receptors [64]. ١١ Because of the effects of biomaterial’s surface properties on the protein’s adsorption, the ١٢ biomaterial properties could directly affect cell responses [54]. However, we still suffer from ١٣ lacking a rational database about the domains involved in this phenomenon and also their precise ١٤ mechanisms. In overall, precisely defining which intermolecular forces regulate the protein-١٥ surface interaction is mostly dependent on the particular protein as well as physical, mechanical, ١٦ and chemical properties of the biomaterial’s surface. ١٧
١٨ ١٩ 4. The rise of carbon-family nanomaterials: New roles in medicine ٢٠ In the recent decades, several studies have shown the potential of using carbon-based ٢١ nanomaterials such as CNTs [65-67], graphene [68-70], fullerene [71], QDs [72], DLC [73-75], MCNs ٢٢
Provi si a
l
12
[76], and CNFs [77] in various biomedical applications. The first reports on the ١ Buckminsterfullerene (shortened to fullerene or buckyball) were the first attempts on innovative ٢ nano-carbons, leading an extraordinary explosion in universal research [71]. However, ND which ٣ is an important member of carbon nanomaterials has been detected in 1963–1982, C60 generally ٤ considered as the earliest detection among symmetric carbon nanomaterials. This discovery ٥ further leads to quick progresses in biomaterials field of study [71, 78]. Fullerenes and NDs have ٦ recently gained a great attention among biomedical scientists, with stress mainly on the field of ٧ cancer diagnosis and therapy [79, 80]. NDs are the products of the famous diamond in nano scale, ٨ which are typically recovered from explosion powder. It has been exhibited that via introducing ٩ nitrogen positions NDs classically could achieve intrinsic fluorescence [81]. Various strategies such ١٠ as diamond nanocrystallites irradiation with helium ions have been suggested for the formation ١١ of fluorescent NDs. In addition, CNTs which have two main categorizes including single-walled ١٢ carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) and multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs), are other key types ١٣ of carbon nanomaterials family that have gained great attentions among biomedical scientists ١٤ since their discovery [66]. SWCNTs are fabricated from graphene sheets which rolled-up to a tube-١٥ shaped arrangement, whereas MWCNTs are formed from a number of incorporated CNTs [82]. It ١٦ has been reported that with the aim of achieving a suitable CNTs for biomedical applications some ١٧ multifaceted purification techniques are essential [82]. Additionally, graphene, as a single 2-١٨ dimensional sheet of carbon, which is the main source of some carbon nanomaterials has been ١٩ currently reported as a promising candidate in various biomedical applications [11]. Some studies ٢٠ have reported the success of applying this kind of carbon in drug delivery systems and tissue ٢١ regeneration applications owing to its large surface area, exceptional mechanical behavior, and ٢٢ Prov si na l
13
easy functionalization [11, 14]. Probable approaches for graphene fabrication are detaching of ١ single graphene layers from bulk graphite through mechanical or physicochemical exfoliation ٢ measures [83, 84]. In addition, some studies have reported fabricating graphene by the ٣ implementation of surfactants. Chemical Vapor Deposition (CVD) is another method which has ٤ been suggested for graphene fabrication [85]. Graphene oxide and reduced graphene oxide are ٥ two derivatives of graphene. In addition, CDs and GQDs, are two other derivatives of graphene ٦ which are generally known as small, quasi one-dimensional graphene particles with broad ٧ applications in bio-imaging [86-90]. These derivatives could be fabricated by the implementation ٨ of some approaches including the carving of graphene, direct wet chemical routes, and ٩ hydrothermal techniques [91, 92]. The structure of different types of carbon-based nanomaterials ١٠ could be observed in figure 2. Recently, biomedical scientists have done many efforts with the aim ١١ of modifying the cellular and molecular responses to carbon nanomaterials via using many ١٢ strategies for carbon nanomaterials surface modification. It has been widely reported that if the ١٣ biocompatibility issue of carbon nanomaterials, which still remains a big challenge in biomaterials ١٤ field of study, solved these nanomaterials owing to their exceptional physicochemical properties ١٥ could suggest some promising diagnostics and treatments clues in medicine. ١٦ . ١٧ Pr vi si l

٤ 5. Impact of physicochemical properties on cellular and molecular responses ٥ It is a well-known fact that the physicochemical properties of biomaterials could have ٦ significant effects on the molecular and cellular responses [94, 95]. There have been several ٧ attempts to explore the potential effects of the physicochemical properties of carbon-based ٨ nanomaterial’s surface on the protein adsorption and subsequently cell responses. However, it ٩ should be taken into consideration that because of the limitations related to precisely analyzing ١٠ the surface topography, the evaluation of results is often challenging. Further, the techniques for ١١
Pr vi
siona
l
15
engineering physical properties of biomaterials’ surfaces could also have an influence on their ١ chemistry properties. Some studies have demonstrated that the topographical surface properties ٢ of carbon-based nanomaterials could regulate the cells behaviors in two ways including; directly ٣ through affecting cytoskeleton or indirectly via protein alignment and unfolding [96-98]. It has ٤ been reported that the surface roughness could potentially increase the hydrophobicity of carbon-٥ based nanomaterials’ surface [99]. In addition, the size of carbon-based nanomaterials could have ٦ a meaningful impact on the molecular and cellular responses [100]. The shape of carbon-based ٧ nanomaterials could also noticeably affect the cellular responses [101]. Electrostatic interactions ٨ also play a role in the biocompatibility of carbon-based nanomaterials owing to the fact that all ٩ the boundaries in fluid solutions are charged, and also the cell membranes have negative charges ١٠ [77, 102]. Electrically conducting carbons which their surface properties could be significantly ١١ changed by applying an electrical potential, have been broadly offered as promising candidates ١٢ for biological applications [67, 103, 104]. The mechanical properties of carbon-based ١٣ nanomaterials could potentially impact on cells as they response in contradiction of the ١٤ biomaterial’s surface and send their reactions to the nucleus about the surroundings [105]. In ١٥ other hands, the chemical properties of carbon-based nanomaterial’s surface, known as ١٦ chemisorption, are highly important in determining the chemical or covalent interactions between ١٧ the surface and cells. Some studies have been doing on investigating the impact of surface chemical ١٨ functionality on cell responses [106]. In fact, several of studies have manipulated the cellular ١٩ responses to the carbon-based nanomaterials by chemically modifying their surfaces. Surfaces ٢٠ carrying functional groups with different hydrophobicity and charges have been demonstrated to ٢١ have impact on the cell responses. Current investigations have demonstrated that besides ٢٢ Provi si na l
16
hydrophobicity/hydrophility, the surface functional groups also highly impact on protein and cell ١ responses [107]. The degradation properties of carbon-based nanomaterials could also have ٢ effects on the molecular and cellular responses. The biological degradability of carbon ٣ nanomaterials is still a challenge despite their broad applications. It has been shown that some ٤ carbon-based nanomaterials could demonstrate asbestos-like pathogenicity, in part owing to the ٥ fiber-like morphology, and also the hypothesis that CNTs are biopersistent. Although, some ٦ researchers have suggested some methods for increasing the biodegradability of these materials ٧ by considering the role of innate immune system in the enzymatic digestion [13, 108]. However, ٨ chemical degradation of these materials has been exhibited by either harsh chemical treatment ٩ with mineral acids140 or degredation of graphitic lattices via inducing high temperatures, these ١٠ methods could not be effective in a biological system [109, 110]. It has been currently shown that ١١ peroxidases which have robust redox potentials, are recognized to catalyze oxidation of foreign ١٢ particles and pathogens with hydrogen peroxide in the body. In addition, the catalytic heme active ١٣ site is a representative of mammalian peroxidases such as neutrophil myeloperoxidase (MPO), ١٤ eosinophil peroxidase (EPO), and lactoperoxidase (LPO), which have been demonstrated to ١٥ catalyze the degradation of carboxylated SWCNTs by producing reactive radical intermediates ١٦ [111] (Figure 3). ١٧

[112] have currently studied a molecular pathway which through ١٢ that macrophages degraded functionalized MWCNTs considered for biological applications with ١٣ having, or not, iron oxide nanoparticles in their internal cavity. Their results indicated that ١٤ intracellularly-induced network defects appear more quickly for iron-free CNTs compared with ١٥ iron-loaded ones, which showed the possible role of iron in the degradation mechanism. They ١٦

CNT ٣ exposure stimulated an oxidative stress-dependent production of iron with Nrf2 nuclear ٤ translocation, Ferritin H and Heme oxygenase 1 translation. Contrariwise, Bach1 was translocated ٥ to the nucleus of cells unprotected to iron-loaded CNTs to recycle embedded iron. In overall, their ٦ outcomes suggested new data on the role of oxidative stress, iron metabolism and Nrf2-mediated ٧ host defense for manipulating CNT fate in macrophages [112]. ٨

Active NOX2 ٣ complex encouraged O2 production. After that, hydroxide radicals ٥ attack CNTs to produce carboxylic acids that form holes in the graphitic arrangement. (a) In the lack of iron ٦ encapsulated into the CNT network, iron employed for Haber-Weiss reaction has to be produced by the cells. ٧ Consequently, oxidative stress products like hydrogen proxide encourage Keap1 cysteine oxidation and free Nrf2 for ٨ nuclear translocation. 6. Carbon-family nanomaterials at the nano-bio interface ١ Although carbon-based nanomaterials have shown exceptional physicochemical ٢ properties that make them suitable candidates for biomedical applications, due to their possible ٣ toxic behavior, their clinical usage still remains challenging. Some studies have been done on ٤ evaluating the biocompatibility of these nanomaterials for biomedical applications. In addition, ٥ several of studies have more currently focused on providing promising surface modification ٦ strategies to enhance the biocompatibility of carbon-based nanomaterials. There is a crucial need ٧ in the literature for separating possible destructive carbon nanomaterials from safe ones. In ٨ biomedical fields of study, it is essential to not make a general view about the toxicity of carbon ٩ nanomaterials, because each class of them has various physicochemical properties which directly ١٠ impact on their biocompatibility profile. Therefore, through carefully assessment of the cellular ١١ and molecular responses to each type of carbon nanomaterials a further promising scenario for ١٢ their biomedical utilization will be provided. For these reasons, in the next sections, the ١٣ physicochemical properties of each type of carbon-based nanomaterials which potentially impact ١٤ on the cellular and molecular responses will be discussed in detail. ١٥

However, some ٦ preparation circumstances have been detected that cause surfactant detachment from CNTs ٧ surface [202]. Chemical functionalization of carbon nanomaterials is another universally used ٨ strategy for enhancing solubility [198]. This approach by using covalently attaching suitable ٩ molecules such as peptides, acids, amines, polymers and poly-L-lysine to the carbon nanomaterials ١٠ surfaces improve their solubility to a great extent [121]. Some studies have reported that the ١١ chemical functionalization of carbon nanomaterials or adsorption of biomolecules is the best ١٢ method for improving the carbon nanomaterials solubility for biomedical applications [211, 212]. ١٣ Burleson et al. [213] have modified the NDs in different acid, base, and organic solutions under ١٤ hydro- and solvo-thermal environments in order to investigate the impacts of adding different ١٥ functional groups onto the surface of NDs on their biocompatibility. They concluded that adding ١٦ functional groups on the surface of NDs is highly dependent on the solvent and process factors. In ١٧ addition, adding CO, OH, or NH functional groups could highly improve the biocompatibility of NDs ١٨ [213]. Additionally, Kabur and his colleagues have reported that the dispersion of fullerene in ١٩ water can be significantly enhanced by adding sulphuric acid on its surface. Moreover, as some ٢٠ studies have reported the sever thrombogenicity of graphene oxide, Singh et al. [214] have ٢١ recently studied the effects of chemical functionalization of this nanomaterial with NH2 on platelet ٢٢ Provi si l
41
responses. After in vivo studies on mice models, they found that the modified graphene oxides did ١ not stimulate platelets responses, pulmonary thromboembolism, and oerythrocytes lysis [214]. ٢
٣ 8. State-of-the-art and future prospective ٤ As above described, carbon-based nanomaterials have exceptional physicochemical ٥ properties which could be highly useful in different biomedical applications such as bio-imaging, ٦ delivery systems, and biosensors. However, due to the scarcity of in vitro and in vivo data in ٧ literature regarding their safety issue in the biological conditions, there is a crucial need to ٨ establish their biocompatibility prior to their clinical usage. Some more in vitro and in vivo ٩ investigations should be also done on the long-term effects of carbon nanomaterials on lung ١٠ toxicity. The contradiction between the obtained results of published papers in the literature ١١ indicates that still much work should be done in establishing the safety of carbon-based ١٢ nanomaterials [121]. However, some in vivo studies in this regard could be seen in the literature, ١٣ many of them have been done on mice models, which owing to the tremendous differences ١٤ between immunological system of human and mice, the achieved results should be taken into ١٥ account with a high caution [215, 216]. In addition, there is a scarcity of information in the ١٦ literature regarding the cytotoxicity effects of carbon nanomaterials on the skin tissue and cells. ١٧ Additionally, as it has been reported that immunological cells had an inflammatory response to ١٨ these materials, the precise FBRs to them should be also taken into consideration [114]. ١٩ Furthermore, as carbon-based materials have different methods of preparation with various ٢٠ degrees of impurities, during investigating their biocompatibility in biological systems considering ٢١ every detail of their physicochemical properties is of great importance. Moreover, the non-٢٢ Pro io l
42
biodegradability of carbon-based nanomaterials is another issue which should be taken into ١ consideration [217]. Owing to the crucial effects of physicochemical properties of carbon ٢ nanomaterials on their biological manner in future studies, better standardization of materials ٣ characterization should be taken into account. In addition, studying the long-term efficacy of each ٤ functionalization method on carbon biological manners and their potential risks should be more ٥ precisely examined. A several of studies have exhibited that using DLC coatings on biomaterials ٦ surfaces provided satisfactory circumstance for the growth of cells without any sign of cytotoxicity ٧ [218]. In addition, DLC coatings meaningfully reduce the wear and corrosion and subsequently ٨ releasing metal ions from orthopedic implants. However, it should be noted that DLC coating ٩ demonstrates a broad range of atomic bond arrangement and properties dependent on the ١٠ deposition situation. Moreover, the adhesion of DLC coating to implants should be more precisely ١١ investigated [218]. Furthermore, regarding graphene oxide, some simple approaches for ١٢ reproducible synthesis and meaningful batch-to-batch characterization of it, should be provided ١٣ to more precisely control its physicochemical properties. Some studies should also be done on ١٤ determining the optimal safe dosage of graphene for biological applications. It has been also ١٥ suggested that owing to the high propensity of graphene oxide to accumulate in lungs, developing ١٦ its design for lung disorders should not be ignored [68, 148, 154]. Besides, some studies have ١٧ revealed that MCNs owing to containing the mixture of mesoporous nanostructure and carbon ١٨ structure, as well as high biocompatibility, could be considered as the next generation of inorganic ١٩ biomaterial systems for biological usages. However, further studies is essential to improve the ٢٠ clinical usage of MCNs [196]. In addition, the analytical apparatuses for revealing and ٢١ characterization of CNTs should be more technologically advanced, as there is now a difficulty of ٢٢ Pr vi si na l
43
studying the precise interactions between biomolecules with carbon nanomaterials. In overall, as ١ there is a huge contradiction between studies that have been done on the safety of carbon-based ٢ nanomaterials for biological applications, far more understanding of this paradox is essential. By ٣ considering this contradiction, it is too early to conclude anything about the safe using of carbon-٤ based nanomaterials in tissue-engineered scaffolds. ٥
٦ 9. Conclusion ٧ In summary, here we have reviewed the current research developments of using carbon-٨ based nanomaterials in biomedical applications by improving their interactions at the nano-bio ٩ interface. A vast number of papers have been published in the recent years which suggested some ١٠ promising approaches for achieving better biological responses to these types of nanomaterials. ١١ However, additional development and utilization are still instantly anticipated. There is a paradox ١٢ between studies that have investigated the biocompatibility of carbon nanomaterials due to ١٣ various kinds of preparation and modification approaches, which finally lead to have very ١٤ dissimilar physicochemical properties. To sum up, the main problems regarding using these ١٥ materials are their slow or non-degradability as well as particle aggregation and agglomeration, ١٦ which should be solved before any biological usage. In addition, there is a crucial need for long-١٧ term in vitro and in vivo investigation of cellular and molecular responses to each physicochemical ١٨ property of these nanomaterials. The use of carbon nanomaterials for various biomedical ١٩ applications such as bioimaging, drug delivery, and biosensing provides a challenging but ٢٠ hypothetically worthwhile chance to progress the next generation of engineered nanomaterials. ٢١ Pro i sio a l
